Movement of Substances into or Out of the Cells

Key Concepts

  • Concentration gradient: The difference in concentration between two regions.
  • Diffusion: The net movement of particles from a region of higher concentration to a region of lower concentration, down a concentration gradient.
  • Active transport: The movement of particles through a cell membrane, from a region of their lower concentration to a region of their higher concentration.

Processes / Mechanisms

  1. Diffusion: Particles of perfume evaporate to become a gas and spread outwards through a process called diffusion.
  2. Active transport: Cells use energy from respiration to move particles through the cell membrane from a region of lower concentration to a region of higher concentration.

Comparisons & Tables

Factor Diffusion Active Transport
Where it occurs Gas Cell membrane
Measurement Not stated in source Not stated in source
Effect on concentration Particles move down the concentration gradient Particles move against the concentration gradient

Applications / Examples

  • Diffusion of water and oxygen into and out of cells: Cells obtain food and oxygen from all sides, and they can carry out activities like growth efficiently.
  • Active transport of nutrients and waste products: Cells use active transport to move materials in and out of the cell.
